natural problem: Cybil and Ronda are sisters. The 10 letters from their names are placed on identical cards so that each of 10 cards contains one letter. Without replacement, two cards are selected at random from the 10 cards. What is the probability that one letter is from each sister's name? Express your answer as a common fraction.
natural solution: The probability that the first letter selected will be from Cybil's name, and the second from Ronda's name, will be $\frac{5}{10}\cdot \frac{5}{9}=\frac{5}{18}$.

Similarly, the probability that the first letter will be from Ronda's name, and the second from Cybil's name, is also $\frac{5}{10}\cdot \frac{5}{9}=\frac{5}{18}$. The probability that one letter will be selected from each name is then $\frac{5}{18}+\frac{5}{18}=\boxed{\frac{5}{9}}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes Cybil Ronda :: "real set" and P :: real
assumes h0 : "finite Cybil"
and h1 : "card Cybil = 5"
and h2 : "finite Ronda"
and h3 : "card Ronda = 5"
and h4 : "Cybil \<inter> Ronda = {}"
and h5 : "P = (\<Sum> c1 \<in> Cybil. \<Sum> r1 \<in> Ronda. (1::real)) / (\<Sum> i \<in> Cybil \<union> Ronda. \<Sum> j \<in> (Cybil \<union> Ronda) - {i}. (1::real))"
shows  "P = 5 / 9"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Cybil and Ronda are sisters. The 10 letters from their names are placed on identical cards so that each of 10 cards contains one letter. Without replacement, two cards are selected at random from the 10 cards. What is the probability that one letter is from each sister's name? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{5}{9}
 ### Proof
 The probability that the first letter selected will be from Cybil's name, and the second from Ronda's name, will be $\frac{5}{10}\cdot \frac{5}{9}=\frac{5}{18}$.
 Similarly, the probability that the first letter will be from Ronda's name, and the second from Cybil's name, is also $\frac{5}{10}\cdot \frac{5}{9}=\frac{5}{18}$. The probability that one letter will be selected from each name is then $\frac{5}{18}+\frac{5}{18}=\boxed{\frac{5}{9}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes Cybil Ronda :: "real set" and P :: real
assumes h0 : "finite Cybil"
and h1 : "card Cybil = 5"
and h2 : "finite Ronda"
and h3 : "card Ronda = 5"
and h4 : "Cybil \<inter> Ronda = {}"
and h5 : "P = (\<Sum> c1 \<in> Cybil. \<Sum> r1 \<in> Ronda. (1::real)) / (\<Sum> i \<in> Cybil \<union> Ronda. \<Sum> j \<in> (Cybil \<union> Ronda) - {i}. (1::real))"
shows  "P = 5 / 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Cybil and Ronda each have 5 unique items in their respective sets. There is no overlap between the items in Cybil's set and Ronda's set. Calculate the probability, P, of selecting an item from Cybil's set and an item from Ronda's set, divided by the total possible pairwise selections among both sets (without selecting the same item twice). The final answer is $\frac{5}{9}$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes cybil_cards ronda_cards :: "nat"
assumes h0 : "cybil_cards = 5"
and h1 : "ronda_cards = 5"
shows  "probability_of_one_letter_from_each_sister = 5 / 9"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Cybil and Ronda are sisters. The 10 letters from their names are placed on identical cards so that each of 10 cards contains one letter. Without replacement, two cards are selected at random from the 10 cards. What is the probability that one letter is from each sister's name? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{5}{9}
 ### Proof
 The probability that the first letter selected will be from Cybil's name, and the second from Ronda's name, will be $\frac{5}{10}\cdot \frac{5}{9}=\frac{5}{18}$.
 Similarly, the probability that the first letter will be from Ronda's name, and the second from Cybil's name, is also $\frac{5}{10}\cdot \frac{5}{9}=\frac{5}{18}$. The probability that one letter will be selected from each name is then $\frac{5}{18}+\frac{5}{18}=\boxed{\frac{5}{9}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes cybil_cards ronda_cards :: "nat"
assumes h0 : "cybil_cards = 5"
and h1 : "ronda_cards = 5"
shows  "probability_of_one_letter_from_each_sister = 5 / 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Cybil has 5 cards, each with a different letter, and Ronda also has 5 cards, each with a different letter. If you randomly draw one card from each sister, what is the probability that both cards have the same letter? The final answer is $\frac{5}{9}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: real
assumes h0 : "P = (\<lambda> cards_chosen. \<exists> c1 c2. c1 \<in> set 'Cybil' \<and> c2 \<in> set 'Ronda' \<and> cards_chosen = {c1, c2})"
shows  "prob h0 = 5 / 9"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Cybil and Ronda are sisters. The 10 letters from their names are placed on identical cards so that each of 10 cards contains one letter. Without replacement, two cards are selected at random from the 10 cards. What is the probability that one letter is from each sister's name? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{5}{9}
 ### Proof
 The probability that the first letter selected will be from Cybil's name, and the second from Ronda's name, will be $\frac{5}{10}\cdot \frac{5}{9}=\frac{5}{18}$.
 Similarly, the probability that the first letter will be from Ronda's name, and the second from Cybil's name, is also $\frac{5}{10}\cdot \frac{5}{9}=\frac{5}{18}$. The probability that one letter will be selected from each name is then $\frac{5}{18}+\frac{5}{18}=\boxed{\frac{5}{9}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: real
assumes h0 : "P = (\<lambda> cards_chosen. \<exists> c1 c2. c1 \<in> set 'Cybil' \<and> c2 \<in> set 'Ronda' \<and> cards_chosen = {c1, c2})"
shows  "prob h0 = 5 / 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Cybil and Ronda each have a set of cards. What is the probability that when choosing one card from each set, the chosen cards form the set specified by the function $P$? The final answer is $\frac{5}{9}$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes cybil_cards ronda_cards total_cards :: real
assumes h0 : "cybil_cards = 5"
and h1 : "ronda_cards = 5"
and h2 : "total_cards = cybil_cards + ronda_cards"
and h3 : "prob_one_letter_from_each = (cybil_cards / total_cards) * (ronda_cards / (total_cards - 1))"
shows  "prob_one_letter_from_each = 5 / 9"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Cybil and Ronda are sisters. The 10 letters from their names are placed on identical cards so that each of 10 cards contains one letter. Without replacement, two cards are selected at random from the 10 cards. What is the probability that one letter is from each sister's name? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{5}{9}
 ### Proof
 The probability that the first letter selected will be from Cybil's name, and the second from Ronda's name, will be $\frac{5}{10}\cdot \frac{5}{9}=\frac{5}{18}$.
 Similarly, the probability that the first letter will be from Ronda's name, and the second from Cybil's name, is also $\frac{5}{10}\cdot \frac{5}{9}=\frac{5}{18}$. The probability that one letter will be selected from each name is then $\frac{5}{18}+\frac{5}{18}=\boxed{\frac{5}{9}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes cybil_cards ronda_cards total_cards :: real
assumes h0 : "cybil_cards = 5"
and h1 : "ronda_cards = 5"
and h2 : "total_cards = cybil_cards + ronda_cards"
and h3 : "prob_one_letter_from_each = (cybil_cards / total_cards) * (ronda_cards / (total_cards - 1))"
shows  "prob_one_letter_from_each = 5 / 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Cybil and Ronda each have 5 letter cards. They combine their cards, and then they randomly pick one card each, one after the other. What is the probability that they each pick one of their own cards? The final answer is $\frac{5}{9}$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes cybil_cards ronda_cards :: "nat set"
and total_cards :: "nat set"
and probability :: real
assumes h0 : "card cybil_cards = 5"
and h1 : "card ronda_cards = 5"
and h2 : "total_cards = cybil_cards \<union> ronda_cards"
and h3 : "card total_cards = 10"
and h4 : "probability = (card cybil_cards * card ronda_cards) / (card total_cards * (card total_cards - 1))"
shows  "probability = 5 / 9"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Cybil and Ronda are sisters. The 10 letters from their names are placed on identical cards so that each of 10 cards contains one letter. Without replacement, two cards are selected at random from the 10 cards. What is the probability that one letter is from each sister's name? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{5}{9}
 ### Proof
 The probability that the first letter selected will be from Cybil's name, and the second from Ronda's name, will be $\frac{5}{10}\cdot \frac{5}{9}=\frac{5}{18}$.
 Similarly, the probability that the first letter will be from Ronda's name, and the second from Cybil's name, is also $\frac{5}{10}\cdot \frac{5}{9}=\frac{5}{18}$. The probability that one letter will be selected from each name is then $\frac{5}{18}+\frac{5}{18}=\boxed{\frac{5}{9}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes cybil_cards ronda_cards :: "nat set"
and total_cards :: "nat set"
and probability :: real
assumes h0 : "card cybil_cards = 5"
and h1 : "card ronda_cards = 5"
and h2 : "total_cards = cybil_cards \<union> ronda_cards"
and h3 : "card total_cards = 10"
and h4 : "probability = (card cybil_cards * card ronda_cards) / (card total_cards * (card total_cards - 1))"
shows  "probability = 5 / 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Cybil and Ronda each have 5 cards, and the cards are all different. They combine their cards to form a set of 10 unique cards. What is the probability that if two cards are randomly drawn from the combined set, one is from Cybil's set and one is from Ronda's set? The final answer is $\frac{5}{9}$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes cybil_cards ronda_cards total_cards :: real
assumes h0 : "cybil_cards = 5"
and h1 : "ronda_cards = 5"
and h2 : "total_cards = 10"
shows  "((cybil_cards / total_cards) * (ronda_cards / (total_cards - 1))) + 
       ((ronda_cards / total_cards) * (cybil_cards / (total_cards - 1))) = 5 / 9"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Cybil and Ronda are sisters. The 10 letters from their names are placed on identical cards so that each of 10 cards contains one letter. Without replacement, two cards are selected at random from the 10 cards. What is the probability that one letter is from each sister's name? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{5}{9}
 ### Proof
 The probability that the first letter selected will be from Cybil's name, and the second from Ronda's name, will be $\frac{5}{10}\cdot \frac{5}{9}=\frac{5}{18}$.
 Similarly, the probability that the first letter will be from Ronda's name, and the second from Cybil's name, is also $\frac{5}{10}\cdot \frac{5}{9}=\frac{5}{18}$. The probability that one letter will be selected from each name is then $\frac{5}{18}+\frac{5}{18}=\boxed{\frac{5}{9}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes cybil_cards ronda_cards total_cards :: real
assumes h0 : "cybil_cards = 5"
and h1 : "ronda_cards = 5"
and h2 : "total_cards = 10"
shows  "((cybil_cards / total_cards) * (ronda_cards / (total_cards - 1))) + 
       ((ronda_cards / total_cards) * (cybil_cards / (total_cards - 1))) = 5 / 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Cybil and Ronda each have 5 cards, making a total of 10 cards. If they each draw a card at random without replacement, what is the probability that both of them draw a card from their own set of cards? The final answer is $\frac{5}{9}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes cybil_cards ronda_cards total_cards :: nat
and prob :: real
assumes h0 : "cybil_cards = 5"
and h1 : "ronda_cards = 5"
and h2 : "total_cards = cybil_cards + ronda_cards"
and h3 : "prob = (cybil_cards * ronda_cards) / (total_cards * (total_cards - 1))"
shows  "prob = 5 / 9"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Cybil and Ronda are sisters. The 10 letters from their names are placed on identical cards so that each of 10 cards contains one letter. Without replacement, two cards are selected at random from the 10 cards. What is the probability that one letter is from each sister's name? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{5}{9}
 ### Proof
 The probability that the first letter selected will be from Cybil's name, and the second from Ronda's name, will be $\frac{5}{10}\cdot \frac{5}{9}=\frac{5}{18}$.
 Similarly, the probability that the first letter will be from Ronda's name, and the second from Cybil's name, is also $\frac{5}{10}\cdot \frac{5}{9}=\frac{5}{18}$. The probability that one letter will be selected from each name is then $\frac{5}{18}+\frac{5}{18}=\boxed{\frac{5}{9}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes cybil_cards ronda_cards total_cards :: nat
and prob :: real
assumes h0 : "cybil_cards = 5"
and h1 : "ronda_cards = 5"
and h2 : "total_cards = cybil_cards + ronda_cards"
and h3 : "prob = (cybil_cards * ronda_cards) / (total_cards * (total_cards - 1))"
shows  "prob = 5 / 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Cybil has 5 cards, and Ronda has 5 cards. What is the probability that if two cards are drawn from the combined set of 10 cards without replacement, one card is from Cybil and one card is from Ronda? The final answer is $\frac{5}{9}$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B :: "real set" and P :: "real set \<Rightarrow> real set \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "A = {1..5}"
and h1 : "B = {6..10}"
and h2 : "card A = 5"
and h3 : "card B = 5"
and h4 : "P = (\<lambda> A B. real (card A * card B) / real ((card A + card B) * ((card A + card B) - 1)))"
shows  "P A B = 5 / 9"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Cybil and Ronda are sisters. The 10 letters from their names are placed on identical cards so that each of 10 cards contains one letter. Without replacement, two cards are selected at random from the 10 cards. What is the probability that one letter is from each sister's name? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{5}{9}
 ### Proof
 The probability that the first letter selected will be from Cybil's name, and the second from Ronda's name, will be $\frac{5}{10}\cdot \frac{5}{9}=\frac{5}{18}$.
 Similarly, the probability that the first letter will be from Ronda's name, and the second from Cybil's name, is also $\frac{5}{10}\cdot \frac{5}{9}=\frac{5}{18}$. The probability that one letter will be selected from each name is then $\frac{5}{18}+\frac{5}{18}=\boxed{\frac{5}{9}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B :: "real set" and P :: "real set \<Rightarrow> real set \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "A = {1..5}"
and h1 : "B = {6..10}"
and h2 : "card A = 5"
and h3 : "card B = 5"
and h4 : "P = (\<lambda> A B. real (card A * card B) / real ((card A + card B) * ((card A + card B) - 1)))"
shows  "P A B = 5 / 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem:
Given two sets A and B, where A contains numbers from 1 to 5 and B contains numbers from 6 to 10, find the value of the function P defined as follows: 

$P(A, B) = \frac{|A| \cdot |B|}{(|A| + |B|) \cdot (|A| + |B| - 1)}$, 

where $|A|$ and $|B|$ represent the number of elements in sets A and B, respectively. The final answer is $\frac{5}{9}$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes cybil_cards ronda_cards selected_cards :: nat
assumes h0 : "cybil_cards = 5"
and h1 : "ronda_cards = 5"
and h2 : "selected_cards = 2"
and h3 : "cybil_cards + ronda_cards = 10"
shows  "((5 choose selected_cards) * (5 choose (selected_cards - 1))) / (10 choose selected_cards) = 5 / 9"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Cybil and Ronda are sisters. The 10 letters from their names are placed on identical cards so that each of 10 cards contains one letter. Without replacement, two cards are selected at random from the 10 cards. What is the probability that one letter is from each sister's name? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{5}{9}
 ### Proof
 The probability that the first letter selected will be from Cybil's name, and the second from Ronda's name, will be $\frac{5}{10}\cdot \frac{5}{9}=\frac{5}{18}$.
 Similarly, the probability that the first letter will be from Ronda's name, and the second from Cybil's name, is also $\frac{5}{10}\cdot \frac{5}{9}=\frac{5}{18}$. The probability that one letter will be selected from each name is then $\frac{5}{18}+\frac{5}{18}=\boxed{\frac{5}{9}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes cybil_cards ronda_cards selected_cards :: nat
assumes h0 : "cybil_cards = 5"
and h1 : "ronda_cards = 5"
and h2 : "selected_cards = 2"
and h3 : "cybil_cards + ronda_cards = 10"
shows  "((5 choose selected_cards) * (5 choose (selected_cards - 1))) / (10 choose selected_cards) = 5 / 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Cybil and Ronda each have 5 cards, and they combine their cards to make a deck of 10 cards. If 2 cards are selected from the deck, what is the probability that one card is from Cybil's cards and the other card is from Ronda's cards? The final answer is $\frac{5}{9}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes Cybil Ronda :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "card Cybil = 5"
and h1 : "card Ronda = 5"
and h2 : "Cybil \<inter> Ronda = {}"
and h3 : "card (Cybil \<union> Ronda) = 10"
shows  "probability (\<lambda> (c1, c2). c1 \<in> Cybil \<and> c2 \<in> Ronda \<or> c1 \<in> Ronda \<and> c2 \<in> Cybil) = 5 / 9"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Cybil and Ronda are sisters. The 10 letters from their names are placed on identical cards so that each of 10 cards contains one letter. Without replacement, two cards are selected at random from the 10 cards. What is the probability that one letter is from each sister's name? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{5}{9}
 ### Proof
 The probability that the first letter selected will be from Cybil's name, and the second from Ronda's name, will be $\frac{5}{10}\cdot \frac{5}{9}=\frac{5}{18}$.
 Similarly, the probability that the first letter will be from Ronda's name, and the second from Cybil's name, is also $\frac{5}{10}\cdot \frac{5}{9}=\frac{5}{18}$. The probability that one letter will be selected from each name is then $\frac{5}{18}+\frac{5}{18}=\boxed{\frac{5}{9}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes Cybil Ronda :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "card Cybil = 5"
and h1 : "card Ronda = 5"
and h2 : "Cybil \<inter> Ronda = {}"
and h3 : "card (Cybil \<union> Ronda) = 10"
shows  "probability (\<lambda> (c1, c2). c1 \<in> Cybil \<and> c2 \<in> Ronda \<or> c1 \<in> Ronda \<and> c2 \<in> Cybil) = 5 / 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Cybil and Ronda each have a set of 5 distinct cards, and their sets do not overlap. If a card is randomly drawn from each of their sets, what is the probability that one card is from Cybil's set and the other is from Ronda's set? The final answer is $\frac{5}{9}$.
